The VX Phenomenon

04/03/2014

With its popularity growing rapidly on campus, VX captain Jack Brown challenges Lewis Hill to a game and talks about the intracacies of the sport

Image by

By undefined undefined

Like a lot of other people, I had never heard of VX. My colleagues at Nouse Sport "reliably" informed me that it was in essence lacrosse but using those over-sized cotton buds from the popular television show Gladiators. Suffice to say, that is not what VX is. It's actually one of the most fast-paced, energetic sports that you can play on a squash court or in a sports hall. There are numerous forms of the game. It can be played as a five versus five team sport across the length of a sports hall or as the game that I tried my hand at, V2: a one against one battle on a squash court. The game is remarkably simple. You play two halves of four minutes each and try to hit your opponent on the body with a soft tennis ball using a stick which has a scoop at either end. You earn one point for hitting your opponent and two points for catching the ball again after hitting your opponent. I met with Jack Brown, who is officially the sixth best player in world (although he decided to tell me this after I had played him!) Jack is trying to establish VX as an official university sport here in York and considering that the sport was first created in Yorkshire it seems like the ideal place to set it up. Other universities such as Loughborough and Leeds Met have teams, but Jack assures me that Northumbria University are the team to beat. I asked how he is planning to make VX an official sport at the University. "Essentially I turned up here for the first year of my degree and I've been liaising with Cass Brown to have the sport set up as an actual university sport. I've been going through the steps, getting signatures from people who are interested and signatures to get people to sign up and then just literally running the club off my own back." It's clear that Jack is the one of the few people at this university who can run the VX club; his enthusiasm is evident from the start. It appears as if he's been playing the sport all his life but I'm surprised to hear that he only took it up two and half years ago. "I started off by gaining a Level Two coaching course through a guy who I knew called Conrad Broughton, who is the head coach of the Scunthorpe club. I helped him a bit with some voluntary work and he offered me the chance to do a coaching qualification." From there, it becomes apparent that Jack's VX career has snowballed rapidly. "Turning up on the day I enjoyed it, I continued playing from then on. A couple of months after that I got a Level Two refereeing qualification. The next year I gained recognition as a player and got accepted into the England Youth Training Programme. That year I then played in the Youth World Cup for V2, [in which] I finished fifth. "Then the next year I went up to senior level and played in the V2 World Cup and came sixth; and then after playing in the World Cup I then went for my Level Three coaching course which I gained. That brings us to about now, where I've been offered and have accepted the role of lead coach for the England VX university squad." It becomes apparent that Jack is quite clearly not only a very talented player but also a very talented coach, who will look to lead some of the country's finest players at the VX Games in America in 2015 to compete against students from several different continents. Indeed, VX is a sport that has grown rapidly in recent times with the sport being played not just in Europe and America but Africa and Asia as well. Jack's coaching talents become apparent as soon as we step onto the court. He gives me some pointers on how to scoop the ball up using the stick to prevent me from fumbling my way round the court chasing the ball from wall to wall. He then gives me some tips on how to launch the ball, telling me to put my dominant hand in the middle of the stick and my weaker one near the base of the stick and launch the ball downwards in some sort of lever motion. Initially I do the exact opposite launching the ball upwards and nearly onto the squash court balcony. However, I soon get the hang of it and start launching balls left, right and centre trying to beat my opponent into submission. Unfortunately Jack is my opponent and in the first practice match it becomes apparent why he is one of the best players in the world. He is quick, agile and energetic and the speed at which he picks up the ball is ridiculously fast. This is emphasised even more when you compare it to my pathetic attempts to scoop the ball up, during which he repeatedly fires tennis balls in my direction and it really is a baptism by fire. In fact, Jack tells me that he has the world's fastest pick up in the game and that his style of play is very fast-paced. Again, he waited till after he played me to tell me that! What's more, the sport is physically tiring and although there are rest periods when you are defending yourself from an advancing opponent who is trying to get close to you so he can hit you and then catch the ball off of you, the match is nonetheless very tiring. After the match, the evidence of the fast-paced nature of the game becomes apparent all over my shirt in the form of sweat. Bucket loads of it. Nice. I then play a practice match against another of the University's VX players, Orjan Holm, who is looking to enter the Lower Division World Cup at the end of year. I'm being outclassed by Orjan who tactically blocks me in the corners of the squash court and repeatedly catches the tennis balls off of my body to rack up the points. The match finishes 31-9 and my attempt to crush the VX players fails miserably. Despite this loss, Jack assures me it's not a thrashing, giving me an example of how his younger brother beat a young Scottish girl 126-26. Now that is a thrashing! That in itself though is another positive of this sport, it can be played by both men and women, either pitted against one another in V2 or across the whole sports hall on the same team. When asked what he would say to try and entice people to go and play VX, Jack said: "It's different, it's energetic, it gives you a huge adrenaline rush and we've not had a bad word said about it yet!" I can't say a bad word about it either. VX is at the heart of the matter, a fast, energetic and highly enjoyable sport and I for one am looking forward to watching it grow at this university.
